title: Introduction to the LarKC workshop

author: Barry Bishop, IRIS Research Unit, University of Innsbruck

segmentation: Welcome everybody, thank you for coming thanks your interest in Lark is good to see.
We've had quite a few participants registered and have attended.
My name is Barry Bishop from STI Innsbruck and where one of the technology partners in Lark and.
Yeah, we we've.
Range to kind of.
Sort of food program for you.
The idea of the workshop is really is more of a tutorial.
We want to give you some sort of advance understanding of what we've been doing in the project and some of the technology that we've developed.
Some of the ideas are not fully developed yet, but some of them we've kind of formulated quite strong ideas about how we're going to arrange the architecture of the project.

In order to make this more sense, sensible though, rather than just diving with some hands-on stuff that wouldn't have any context, we've kind of front loaded the whole day with a few presentations about the architecture and the data model that we're using, and some of the technology that will later see in use during the hands-on scenarios.
I suggest during the day that if at any point if there are questions in any presentation at any point you just say and we deal with them straight away.
The agenda I'm going to hand over in a few moments to Frank Van Harmelen.
He's the scientific director of the project from the Free University of Amsterdam, and he's going to give you an overall picture of the project and what our research goals are.

Following that, as a kind of 1st little bit of hands on, I'm going to show you something we've been doing with some rule based reasoning inside large, and we're going to use this as like the Hello World example.

So during this first part of this will be setting up some of the code, and that's when we'll be using Eclipse and installing some software, importing some stuff and then dealing with any problems why stuff doesn't work, and so on.
And then we're just going to play around a bit with.
With this scenario and play around with some rulesets and and that kind of thing.
Afterwards, even from under text will be giving you a little presentation about the data model.
This is about the data structures in the storage techniques that we're using in the project for managing large amounts of data an for passing data between.
The plugins which we learn about in the moment.
Then we are going to have a presentation from Allah belief about the distributed processing lock, which is more about some of the experiments we've been doing.
The next phase of the project.

We're really going to be concentrating on the distributed in parallel part of reasoning and as such at the moment we have some ideas and some experiments and we've just been experimenting with possible techniques there, so he's going to tell you a bit about that.
After lunch we are going to have a presentation of hands-on session from Flash Fortuna from Jsi.
He's going to go through a scenario involving a couple of plugins, one of which is the psych reasoner, and another one this gate platform.
And you can show you a combination of using these things together and some interesting things that can be done there.
Then after that, we're going to have presentation from Al about the degrees.
Now there's the.
To them they developed a kind of wrapper plugin which can wrap any DL reasoner which supports the dig interface, the.
Discription Logic, Interface Group and then you can slot in different reasons under there and we can plug that into the lock platform.
And then after coffee.
Today we're going to have a talk from Alexi about the development environment that is going to be made public for the world to download and be involved with.
It's a G Forge setup and he's going to tell you a little bit about where things are and what we can do with that.
And then finally in the wrap up, we just left a bit of time for some open discussions and for feedback, which we very much appreciate.
And to discuss some ideas of what you think we could do in the future things.
Maybe you might want to play around with yourselves.
Just one thing we this is the first.
This is the first workshop we've done like this, so we're not entirely sure with the way mitan.
We'd appreciate as much feedback as possible on the USB sticks.
There's a questionnaire which if you could fill in at any point during the day and either email or give to us or whatever, then that would really help us for the next tutorial that we run.
